title: 106_hr1269
content: The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" may impose sanctions for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties, including civil penalties. Sec. 109 of the "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" prohibits royalty violations, including failure to comply with requirements, make required payments, or submit false information related to royalty payments. The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" prohibits royalty violations, including failure to comply with requirements, make payments, or submit false information related to royalty payments. Violators may face penalties of up to three times the unpaid royalty amount plus interest, as well as a $25,000 civil penalty per violation per day. Violations can be exempted if reported and corrected within 30 days. The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" imposes penalties for lease administration violations, such as failure to notify the Secretary of designations or assignments, refusal to permit entry or inspection, non-compliance with production notification requirements, and incorrect reporting of information. The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" imposes penalties for violations related to lease administration, including failure to report necessary records, theft of oil or gas, and repeated violations. Penalties can range up to $10,000 per violation for lease management issues and up to $25,000 per violation for theft of oil or gas. If a person repeatedly violates lease administration regulations, they must correct the violations within 30 days of notification. Failure to comply will result in a civil penalty three times the original amount. Additionally, the Secretary may impose further penalties for continued violations or lease management orders. The Secretary has the authority to take various actions against a person who repeatedly violates lease administration regulations, including shutting down production, prohibiting the acquisition of new leases, canceling or transferring existing leases, and collecting reimbursement for costs incurred. Administrative appeals can be made regarding royalty determinations. The Secretary has the authority to impose royalties or civil penalties, which can be appealed within 15 days. The final determination will be made by the Secretary or designee. Penalties can be deducted from sums owed by the United States, and the Secretary has the discretion to compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties will be served personally by an authorized representative of the Secretary. The Secretary can impose penalties, which can be appealed within 15 days. The amount of the penalty and reasons for it will be stated on record. Judicial review can be sought in the district court for aggrieved parties. The Secretary can impose penalties that can be appealed within 15 days. Failure to pay a civil penalty within 90 days after the final order can result in a court-awarded judgment to pay the assessed amount plus interest. No liability for civil penalties under subsections (a) or (b) for failure to comply with the Mineral Leasing Act. The Secretary can impose penalties for violations of subsections (a), (b)(2), or (b)(4) which can toll the statute of limitations for oil and gas leases until the violations are corrected or a final order is issued. The Secretary can impose penalties for violations of subsections (a), (b)(2), or (b)(4) related to oil and gas leases. Records must be maintained until released from the obligation or the expiration of the required period. Amounts received from penalties for underpayment of royalties are treated as royalties paid under the lease for mineral leasing laws and the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act. SEC. 3. SHARED CIVIL PENALTIES. Amends Section 206 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act to include trebled royalties or 50% of any civil penalty.
